claim: The most expensive color in the world is Blue.

supporting.text: Historically, the pigment ultramarine blue, derived from lapis lazuli, was more expensive than gold during the Renaissance due to its rarity and labor-intensive extraction process.

attacks.text: Historically, the pigment ultramarine blue, derived from lapis lazuli, was more expensive than gold during the Renaissance due to its rarity and labor-intensive extraction process.
Modern synthetic ultramarine blue is mass-produced and very inexpensive, making historical rarity irrelevant to current pricing.
Other pigments like Vantablack or certain proprietary red pigments are currently more expensive than any blue pigment.
The claim specifies 'in the world' without temporal context, so historical pricing alone cannot support it definitively.
Lapis lazuli is still mined today, and while valuable, it is not the most expensive material in the world.

supporting.text: Synthetic blue pigments like YInMn Blue, discovered in 2009, are costly to produce due to their complex chemical composition and specialized manufacturing requirements.

attacks.text: Synthetic blue pigments like YInMn Blue, discovered in 2009, are costly to produce due to their complex chemical composition and specialized manufacturing requirements.
Natural blue pigments like ultramarine, derived from lapis lazuli, are historically more expensive than synthetic alternatives due to rarity and extraction costs.
Ultramarine's cost has significantly decreased since the development of synthetic substitutes in the 19th century, making it less expensive than modern synthetic pigments like YInMn Blue.
Some synthetic blue dyes used in textiles and plastics are mass-produced at very low costs, contradicting the claim that blue is universally expensive.
Mass-produced blue dyes are chemically distinct from high-end pigments like YInMn Blue and cannot be compared in terms of production cost or value.

supporting.text: Certain red pigments, such as Carmine, derived from cochineal insects, can be more expensive than blue pigments due to the labor-intensive harvesting process.

attacks.text: Certain red pigments, such as Carmine, derived from cochineal insects, can be more expensive than blue pigments due to the labor-intensive harvesting process.
Ultramarine blue, historically made from lapis lazuli, was more expensive than carmine due to the rarity of the mineral and the complex extraction process.
Synthetic ultramarine blue is now widely available, reducing its cost significantly compared to natural carmine, which still requires labor-intensive harvesting.
Even synthetic ultramarine blue can be expensive in high-purity forms used in art restoration and high-end applications.
Other blue pigments, like YInMn blue, are extremely expensive due to their recent discovery and complex manufacturing process.
YInMn blue's cost is offset by its unique properties, such as heat reflectance, making it a niche product rather than a general-use pigment.

supporting.text: Vantablack, a super-black pigment, is currently one of the most expensive colors due to its unique light-absorbing properties and restricted availability.

attacks.text: Vantablack, a super-black pigment, is currently one of the most expensive colors due to its unique light-absorbing properties and restricted availability.
Blue pigments like ultramarine and cobalt blue are historically and currently more expensive than Vantablack due to their rarity and production costs.
Vantablack is not a color in the traditional sense but a material coating, which disqualifies it from being compared to pigments like blue.
The claim specifies 'color,' and Vantablack is often marketed as the 'blackest black,' making it a valid contender for the most expensive color.

supporting.text: The rarity of natural blue dyes like Tyrian purple (technically a shade of blue-purple) made them prohibitively expensive in ancient times, reserved for royalty.

attacks.text: The rarity of natural blue dyes like Tyrian purple (technically a shade of blue-purple) made them prohibitively expensive in ancient times, reserved for royalty.
Modern synthetic blue dyes are mass-produced and inexpensive, making blue no longer the most expensive color today.
Other colors, like certain shades of red or pink, require rare materials or complex processes that make them more expensive than blue today.
Historical rarity does not necessarily translate to modern expense, as production methods and availability have changed drastically.
Even in ancient times, some red dyes like those from cochineal insects were more expensive than blue dyes.

supporting.text: Some green pigments, such as those containing chromium or cobalt, can be more expensive than common blue pigments due to their specialized production processes.

attacks.text: Some green pigments, such as those containing chromium or cobalt, can be more expensive than common blue pigments due to their specialized production processes.
Ultramarine blue, historically made from lapis lazuli, remains one of the most expensive pigments due to its rarity and labor-intensive extraction process.
Modern synthetic ultramarine is widely available and affordable, reducing the relevance of historical lapis lazuli-based pricing.
The claim specifies 'in the world,' implying current market prices where some blue pigments (e.g., YInMn blue) are patented and extremely costly to produce.
Green pigments like viridian or malachite-based ones are also patented or require rare minerals, maintaining their high cost comparable to premium blues.
